author: Anonym
title: I light up less, the decalogue for saving energy - Energia & Energie - The Limited Times
text:
Turn off the lights, give up the car, plant trees, share consumption.
These are some of the actions of the Decalogue of 'M'illumino di meno', the energy saving initiative of the Catrepillar broadcast of Rai Radio 2, which is held on 16 February at the same time as the National Day of Energy Saving and Sustainable Lifestyles.
 The Decalogue invites the first point to turn off and have the lights in the house, office, condominium and municipality turned off.
An anti-waste dinner by candlelight is the second action proposed, with empty-the-fridge recipes and low environmental impact foods.
 The third point is giving up the car for one day, with the choice of walking, cycling, using public transport or shared mobility.
 The fourth action of the Decalogue is to organize awareness-raising activities on the issues of energy efficiency and the climate crisis: talking about it with students, with colleagues, with customers.
The fifth point is planting trees, seedlings and flowers, excellent tools for fighting climate change.
 On the sixth, create a circular economy, putting objects that are no longer used back into circulation, for example with a 'swap party' (a party in which objects are exchanged).
 The seventh proposed action is to share an energy-intensive activity, such as traveling by car or using wi-fi, to reduce consumption and optimize resources.
The eighth point is to organize a non-energy-intensive event, such as an unplugged concert, a training session with reduced lights, an evening of astronomical observation.
 The ninth proposed action is to improve energy efficiency, such as defrosting the fridge or applying a jet aerator to the taps.
 Tenth and final action is to turn down the heating, wearing heavier clothes.
Reproduction reserved © Copyright ANSA

author: Ewan Gale
title: RB upgrades "encouraging" despite Spanish F1 qualifying disaster
text: Daniel Ricciardo has insisted RB's Spanish Grand Prix performance with an upgraded car was "encouraging" despite both drivers missing out on Q2. The Faenza-based outfit had been on the up in recent races and added a number of updates, including a new floor, to the car at the Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya. But having struggled for pace through practice, both Ricciardo and team-mate Yuki Tsunoda failed to advance through to the second part of qualifying, with the Australian managing only the 18th fastest time, a position behind Tsunoda on the grid. On how much the result could be accredited to a lack of understanding with the new components, Ricciardo said: "I'd like to think there's still a bit more on the package to figure out, so that's something we'll keep doing but, on the flip side, I do feel like [in practice] we were much more out of balance and actually today, in quali, the car felt much more together. Read Also: Formula 1F1 Spanish GP: Norris makes last-gasp swoop for pole over Verstappen Formula 1Leclerc, Stroll escape penalties for collisions in Spanish GP practice "I actually didn't think the car felt too bad in quali. Of course, there are some corners where you feel it should be flat there or whatever, so you know you may be still missing a bit of load but in general it was I felt much better than yesterday. "I haven't spoken to Yuki yet but I don't think he was too unhappy with how the car felt. I think we're just not that quick and normally, you put three sets in Q1... it never guarantees you a spot in Q2, but it gives you a much better chance and obviously, to still not make it I think it just shows that we just at the moment don't have the pace with this current config so we'll keep chipping away." Daniel Ricciardo, RB F1 Team VCARB 01 Photo by: Sam Bloxham \/ Motorsport Images Commenting on the work done between Friday and Saturday, Ricciardo added: "Yesterday felt like we were still trying to fight it [the car] a little bit so we did make some bigger changes overnight. "So we probably haven't perfected it right now and maybe that's the encouraging thing but I feel like we did do a good job overnight to get the car in a better place. "So from a feeling, it felt better today. I had more comfort and confidence in it but unfortunately on this thing, the stopwatch, we're still where we were yesterday. "With the floors, when you get a new floor, obviously that's where these cars are so powerful in terms of the load and the aero characteristics, so it's just trying to get on top of that. As I said, I felt like we made a good step today, but when Pierre [Hamelin, race engineer] told me P18, I didn't really have anything to say on the radio because I was honestly quite surprised. "I knew we're not going to be at P10, but I honestly thought that would have been good enough for Q2." Tsunoda was also surprised by his final position, audibly confused at missing out on a place in the top 15 when notified during his in-lap. "The upgrade seems as it is working as we expected. So I think package is working. It's not doing anything strange, but just purely there's something this week... and we tried multiple stuff, obviously, but wasn't able to turn it around. "At least P16 I wanted to hear [on team radio]. But P17 was quite far away from where I wanted or where I was expecting from that lap. At least I feel able to maximise something but, at the same time, quite disappointed hearing P17 from that lap. Suggesting the team had lacked when preparing for the weekend, the Japanese driver added: "Hopefully, it's track-specific but also, we know what we could done better to prepare this week and we know what we are missing to probably make it better from the current situation. "But we couldn't manage to put it [together] this week at least, and that was probably the main limitation."

author: Decatur Daily Democrat
title: My Dent Guy Offers Convenient In-Shop and Mobile Paintless Dent Repair Services in Naples, FL | News | decaturdailydemocrat.com
text: Naples, FL - My Dent Guy, a leading provider of high-quality paintless dent repair services , is pleased to announce its convenient in-shop and mobile services in Naples, FL. With a commitment to exceptional customer service, My Dent Guy is revolutionizing the dent repair industry by offering efficient and cost-effective solutions for vehicles of all makes and models. Paintless dent repair (PDR) is a specialized technique that allows for the removal of dents, dings, and hail damage without the need for traditional bodywork, sanding, or repainting. With over 11 years of experience, My Dent Guy’s PDR expertise has perfected this method, ensuring that customers receive outstanding results with minimal disruption to their daily lives. Convenience is a top priority for My Dent Guy. Understanding that time is valuable, the company offers both in-shop and mobile services to accommodate its customers' busy schedules. Their state-of-the-art facility in Naples, FL, is equipped with cutting-edge tools and equipment, enabling their technicians to handle any dent repair job, from minor door dings to more extensive damage. Customers can drop off their vehicles at the shop, and the skilled technician at My Dent Guy will promptly restore them to their original condition. For those unable to visit the shop, My Dent Guy's mobile service brings the expertise directly to the customer's location. Whether at home, work, or even during a shopping trip, customers can conveniently schedule an appointment, and My Dent Guy's technician will arrive fully equipped to tackle the dent repair on-site. This hassle-free service saves customers time and eliminates the need for multiple trips to the shop. "We understand the stress and inconvenience that dents and dings can cause for vehicle owners," said Mark Tucker, of My Dent Guy. "That's why we are committed to providing our customers in Naples, FL, with exceptional paintless dent repair services that are convenient and affordable. Whether they choose to visit our shop or utilize our mobile service, we guarantee outstanding results and a seamless experience." My Dent Guy's commitment to customer satisfaction extends beyond their repair services. They offer free estimates and competitive pricing, to make the process as smooth as possible. Mark Tucker is dedicated to delivering unparalleled workmanship and attention to detail, ensuring that every customer is thrilled with the results. About My Dent Guy My Dent Guy is a leading provider of paintless dent repair services in Naples, FL. My Dent Guy offers convenient in-shop and mobile services for vehicles of all makes and models. His expertise utilizes state-of-the-art techniques and tools to provide efficient and cost-effective dent repairs, saving customers time and money. For more information or to schedule an appointment, visit www.callmydentguy.com or call 239-564-3368. Media Contact Company Name: My Dent Guy Paintless Dent Repair Contact Person: Mark Tucker Email: Send Email Phone: 239-564-3368 Address:6245 Janes Ln #C City: Naples State: FL Country: United States Website: https://callmydentguy.com/

author: Astha Saxena
title: People vow to 'never eat bacon again' after watching how it's made | nottinghampost - Nottinghamshire Live
text:
The process of making bacon has recently left people surprised, to say the least, with some swearing off the breakfast staple after learning about its production. Archive footage from Discovery Channel UK's "How It's Made" programme, which originally aired in 2018, resurfaced on YouTube and has since caused quite a stir among viewers, many of whom have expressed their "disgust" upon seeing the entire cooking process.
The video reveals how dozens of pork bellies are placed into a large tumbler that spins to soften the meat for easier skin removal.
The documentary noted: "Bacon is now processed and even pre-cooked in factories."
After softening, the bellies are laid out on a conveyor belt, skin-side down, and passed through a slicer to separate the skin. While the skin goes off to become crackling, the meat proceeds to a "flipping device" that turns it over.
Further down the line, workers mix a brine solution to cure the pork. The programme detailed: "Salt is poured into a tank of water and thoroughly mixed until it dissolves. Liquid smoke and flavourings are then added before the bellies pass beneath an 'injector head,' where needles inject the curing solution into the meat," reports the Express.
As the process advances, a "comb" is used to prepare the bellies for hanging on racks. The Discovery Channel presenters explain: "Next, they enter a drench cabinet for a liquid smoke shower."
The process starts by enhancing the flavour and colour before the pork bellies are placed into a large oven, slow-cooked for an extensive five hours at a minimal temperature. After being suffused with taste, the meat undergoes rapid chilling in a blast freezer and then rests in a secondary cooler for two days. The documentary highlights: "Cooling firms the meat, making it easier to slice."
Once ready, the bellies are precisely trimmed to size and carefully screened by passing through a metal detector to ensure no remnants from metal hangers contaminate the meat. The video explains further: "After that, the bellies are wrapped and stored in a freezer until its time to slice them into bacon. Here [in the slice line], workers load the meat into chutes which rotate back and forth over a blade, slicing the bellies into bacon-shaped pieces."
The procedure culminates as the bacon continues down a conveyor belt heading into a browning microwave, where excess fat is siphoned off, later repurposed for gravy and pet food products. The cooked bacon then "exits the microwave oven and is carefully inspected by workers, who remove any broken or subpar rashers."
Lastly, the bacon strips are arranged onto parchment paper by automated wheels, setting the stage for packing.
The revealing video has left numerous viewers stunned, with one commenter admitting: "I have lost so much weight since I've been watching how food is made. All the things I love to eat looks down right gross to me."
One person criticised after viewing the footage: "Oh well, bacon is off the menu for me after watching this video. I have a feeling that ham will be going the same way after seeing what is done to it! ".
Another added their concerns: "Whenever I watch these videos I always think I wonder how often the nasty meat scraps get cleaned off the machines. There's a lot of nooks and crannies for meat to get lost in."
